name: Entity
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity
description:
Entity

Entity represents a Datastore record. Every Entity has a Key, and a list of properties.

Entities in Datastore form a hierarchically structured space similar to the directory structure of a file system. When you create an entity, you can optionally designate another entity as its parent; the new entity is a child of the parent entity.

examples.caption: Create a new entity using a block:
examples.code:
task = datastore.entity "Task", "sampleTask" do |t|
  t["type"] = "Personal"
  t["created"] = Time.now
  t["done"] = false
  t["priority"] = 4
  t["percent_complete"] = 10.0
  t["description"] = "Learn Cloud Datastore"
end

examples.caption: Create a new entity belonging to an existing parent entity:
examples.code:
task_key = datastore.key "Task", "sampleTask"
task_key.parent = datastore.key "TaskList", "default"

task = Gcloud::Datastore::Entity.new
task.key = task_key

task["type"] = "Personal"
task["done"] = false
task["priority"] = 4
task["description"] = "Learn Cloud Datastore"

title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#[]
methods.description:
Retrieve a property value by providing the name.

Property values are converted from the Datastore value type automatically. Blob properties are returned as StringIO objects. Location properties are returned as a Hash with :longitude and :latitude keys.

examples.caption: Properties can be retrieved with a string name:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
task = datastore.find "Task", "sampleTask"
task["description"] #=> "Learn Cloud Datastore"

examples.caption: Or with a symbol name:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
task = datastore.find "Task", "sampleTask"
task[:description] #=> "Learn Cloud Datastore"

examples.caption: Getting a blob value returns a StringIO object:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
user = datastore.find "User", "alice"
user["avatar"] #=> StringIO("\x89PNG\r\n\x1A...")

examples.caption: Getting a geo point value returns a Hash:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
user = datastore.find "User", "alice"
user["location"] #=> { longitude: -122.0862462,
                 #     latitude: 37.4220041 }

examples.caption: Getting a blob value returns a StringIO object:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
user = datastore.find "User", "alice"
user["avatar"] #=> StringIO("\x89PNG\r\n\x1A...")

returns.description: Returns nil if the property doesn’t exist

title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#[]=
methods.description:
Set a property value by name.

Property values are converted to use the proper Datastore value type automatically. Use an IO-compatible object (File, StringIO, Tempfile) to indicate the property value should be stored as a Datastore blob. IO-compatible objects are converted to StringIO objects when they are set. Use a Hash with :longitude and :latitude keys to indicate the property value should be stored as a Geo Point/LatLng.

examples.caption: Properties can be set with a string name:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
task = datastore.find "Task", "sampleTask"
task["description"] = "Learn Cloud Datastore"
task["tags"] = ["fun", "programming"]

examples.caption: Or with a symbol name:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
task = datastore.find "Task", "sampleTask"
task[:description] = "Learn Cloud Datastore"
task[:tags] = ["fun", "programming"]

examples.caption: Setting a blob value using an IO:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
user = datastore.find "User", "alice"
user["avatar"] = File.open "/avatars/alice.png"
user["avatar"] #=> StringIO("\x89PNG\r\n\x1A...")

examples.caption: Setting a geo point value using a Hash:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
user = datastore.find "User", "alice"
user["location"] = { longitude: -122.0862462, latitude: 37.4220041 }

examples.caption: Setting a blob value using an IO:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
user = datastore.find "User", "alice"
user["avatar"] = File.open "/avatars/alice.png"
user["avatar"] #=> StringIO("\x89PNG\r\n\x1A...")

methods.name: properties
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#properties
methods.description: Retrieve properties in a hash-like structure. Properties can be accessed or set by string or symbol.

examples.code:
task.properties[:description] = "Learn Cloud Datastore"
task.properties["description"] #=> "Learn Cloud Datastore"

task.properties.each do |name, value|
  puts "property #{name} has a value of #{value}"
end

examples.caption: A property’s existence can be determined by calling exist?:
examples.code:
task.properties.exist? :description #=> true
task.properties.exist? "description" #=> true
task.properties.exist? :expiration #=> false

examples.caption: A property can be removed from the entity:
examples.code:
task.properties.delete :description
task.save

examples.caption: The properties can be converted to a hash:
examples.code: prop_hash = task.properties.to_h

methods.name: key=
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#key=
methods.description:
Sets the Gcloud::Datastore::Key that identifies the entity.

Once the entity is saved, the key is frozen and immutable. Trying to set a key when immutable will raise a RuntimeError.

examples.caption: The key can be set before the entity is saved:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
task = Gcloud::Datastore::Entity.new
task.key = datastore.key "Task"
datastore.save task

examples.caption: Once the entity is saved, the key is frozen and immutable:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore
task = datastore.find "Task", "sampleTask"
task.persisted? #=> true
task.key = datastore.key "Task" #=> RuntimeError
task.key.frozen? #=> true
task.key.id = 9876543221 #=> RuntimeError

methods.name: persisted?
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#persisted?
methods.description: Indicates if the record is persisted. Default is false.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
datastore = gcloud.datastore

task = Gcloud::Datastore::Entity.new
task.persisted? #=> false

task = datastore.find "Task", "sampleTask"
task.persisted? #=> true

methods.name: exclude_from_indexes?
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#exclude_from_indexes?
methods.description:
Indicates if a property is flagged to be excluded from the Datastore indexes. The default value is false. This is another way of saying that values are indexed by default.

If the property is multi-valued, each value in the list can be managed separately for exclusion from indexing. Calling this method for a multi-valued property will return an array that contains the excluded boolean value for each corresponding value in the property. For example, if a multi-valued property contains ["a", "b"], and only the value "b" is indexed (meaning that "a"’ is excluded), the return value for this method will be [true, false].

examples.caption: Single property values will return a single flag setting:
examples.code:
task["priority"] = 4
task.exclude_from_indexes? "priority" #=> false

examples.caption: A multi-valued property will return an array of flag settings:
examples.code:
task["tags"] = ["fun", "programming"]
task.exclude_from_indexes! "tags", [true, false]

task.exclude_from_indexes? "tags" #=> [true, false]

methods.name: exclude_from_indexes!
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#exclude_from_indexes!
methods.description:
Sets whether a property should be excluded from the Datastore indexes. Setting true will exclude the property from the indexes. Setting false will include the property on any applicable indexes. The default value is false. This is another way of saying that values are indexed by default.

If the property is multi-valued, each value in the list can be managed separately for exclusion from indexing. When you call this method for a multi-valued property, you can pass either a single boolean argument to be applied to all of the values, or an array that contains the boolean argument for each corresponding value in the property. For example, if a multi-valued property contains ["a", "b"], and only the value "b" should be indexed (meaning that "a"’ should be excluded), you should pass the array: [true, false].

examples.code:
entity["priority"] = 4
entity.exclude_from_indexes! "priority", true

examples.caption: Multi-valued properties can be given multiple exclude flags:
examples.code:
entity["tags"] = ["fun", "programming"]
entity.exclude_from_indexes! "tags", [true, false]

examples.caption: Or, a single flag can be applied to all values in a property:
examples.code:
entity["tags"] = ["fun", "programming"]
entity.exclude_from_indexes! "tags", true

examples.caption: Flags can also be set with a block:
examples.code:
entity["priority"] = 4
entity.exclude_from_indexes! "priority" do |priority|
  priority > 4
end

params.name: flag
params.description:
whether the value or values
should be excluded from indexing

params.name: yield
params.description: a block yielding each value of the property

methods.name: serialized_size
title: Gcloud
Datastore
Entity#serialized_size
methods.description: The number of bytes the Entity will take to serialize during API calls.
